Posts.Content: Hi Leea, Thanks for your reply. I am sorry that your diagnosis next was bc. But it sounds like you took very proactive steps. Have you had any side effects from the tamoxifen? Interesting that even with double mast you still have to take it. I see a surgeon next week to have the ADH area removed. Its all a bit overwhelming. Such big decisions. I might reply again after I know more. Thanks again, for sharing your experience.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Sunshine, Welcome! At least we all here on this board have each other as we go through this. You and I sound very similar. I have also lost a sister to BC and a 2nd sister had it as well but is 15 years post diagnosis. It is very scary - quite the wake up call. The good news with ADH is that we are finding it so so early. I keep telling myself that. I have not had my procedure yet, I meet with the anesthesiologist tomorrow and my surgery is next Friday. I'm coming down with a cold so I hope that won't end up pushing the date out. I want to get this over with! When I met with the surgeon, he did confirm what you are saying. He said that 25% of people will have DCIS (non-invasive) and 11% may have invasive cancer. I like to think in terms of the reverse percentages. 75% that I won't have DCIS and 89% that I won't have the invasive kind. The surgeon was great, he took alot of time to explain everything - I hope yours will as well. I will post here how things go. There are one or two other blogs here that we seem to have posted to more than this one. I'll continue to post here as I go through this! Let us know when your appt is and let us know how it goes. This board has been a God-send!
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Sunshine, sorry to hear the surgeon was too busy. I'm so glad you are going for a 2nd opinion. I would definitely not use the doctor that was too busy. Follow your gut. The MRI sounds like the way to go. PF, sorry your situation is so messy in a way, more tests, more xrays, more TIME. I swear that's the hardest part in some ways. It's like why couldn't they have performed those mammos yesterday while they had you there. Its like the Dr. didn't read your chart til you were in their office. Maybe that is the reality of how things work. I'll keep ya'll posted as to how Friday goes. I'm more nervous about what my results will be than the actual procedure. I bravely say right now...
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Sunshine, The surgery went really well. The whole experience was pain free -from the wire insert through surgery. You just wake up and its over. I was very nauseous from the anesthesia. My recommendation to anyone about to go through this is to make sure they give you a prescription for nausea as well in case you need it. Not everyone does. But other than that, from the surgery itself, I only feel a dull ache at the incision site - its not bad at all. I took one pain pill yesterday and none at all today. I do feel tired though. I'll be back at work tomorrow. Now the next wait begins as it will be 5-7 days before I have the results. I'll keep you posted. What's next for you? Let is know when you have your 2nd opinion/MRI, etc.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Christina, The waiting and anticipation is so hard. I'm glad you were able to put it out of your mind for a few weeks. I hope your surgery goes well. I had never had surgery before and was really scared - but found the procedure painless - and not very much discomfort afterwards. I hope the same for you!.. We'll keep an eye out for you here.. Let us know how it goes. Thinking of you!
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Ashland, Glad you found us. So sorry you are having to go through this and I know how hard all of the waiting and wondering is. The biopsy procedure was painless for me also. I know this whole experience is tough - all the what if's that run through your mind. The good thing is that the odds are in your favor for a benign result. Hang in there - let us know how it goes.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Ashland, I'm glad the procedure went well for you. Now more waiting begins. Let us know what you find out - I'm hopeful you will have benign results and can put this all behind you!!!!
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Sunshine, My surgeon has so far not mentioned MRI. But did mention genetic testing - but it sounds like something we will discuss after Friday's biopsy results are known. I don't know when MRI is indicated, but from reading other blogs it seems common. You and I are so similar, both with micro calcs and no lump or mass you can see or feel. I do plan to get a second opinion at Duke once I have the results of this biopsy. Let me know what your surgeon has to say. You too PFretzsch!
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Pat, Christina, LadyAbby and Sarasota, Thanks for your replies throughout this experience. It really means a lot to me right now! I will definitely continue to post. I've known since Wednesday, but just didn't want to type it or say it for a few days. Sounds silly I know. It just means it is real. I will probably start a new topic for this next stage of my unwanted journey. So many questions in my mind, but I keep telling myself that if you have to receive this type of news, this is the best possible stage to have and it has a 98-99% success (not sure you can use the word cure) rate... and for that I am very thankful.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Thanks for the well wishes. I am strangely calm today. I'll let you know how it goes tomorrow.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Virginia, I'm very similar to you, I had a lumpectomy for DCIS followed by radiation. I completed my rad treatments on 8/11. I was terrified to start them - and I did mine in the prone position so I could avoid my lungs as much as possible - I have pretty severe asthma. For me the treatments went pretty darn well. I continued to ride my horse in the heat and humidity during it. I started to get a sunburn after about 10-14 treatments and didn't feel tired until the last week and for a couple of weeks afterwards. You will definitely want to apply lotion - I used Aloe Vera Gel and Lindi products. Many people talked about success using emu oil from Montana. Sounds strange I know but many swear by it. The treatments are so quick - totally painless - just the inconvenience of having to drive there every day for 6 weeks. I met some wonderful women there going through it together was nice - having people to see and talk to that are going through it. I'm happy to share my experience or answer any questions... Now that i'm almost a month out - my skin is pretty much back to normal. I plan to start taking Tamoxifen in October. I'm not looking forward to that but it seems silly not to do everything I can. I hope your simulation went well today. It just feels to odd and scary to be going through it. I know it is a tough time emotionally - so hang in there!!
Posts.Title: Radiation After DCIS - What Side Effects?

Posts.Content: Hi Virginia, Just checking in, have you started your treatement? How did it go. Thinking of you.
Posts.Title: Radiation After DCIS - What Side Effects?

Posts.Content: Same here. I'm not looking forward to starting to take tamox in October. I'm' just now starting to feel back to normal where my life isn't centered around treatment which has been really nice. Let me know how your first day goes. You'll be surprised how quick it is!
Posts.Title: Radiation After DCIS - What Side Effects?

Posts.Content: Hi IllinoisGal - welcome to our group. I'm glad you found us. Please be sure to let us know what you learn tomorrow. Pat I loved your summary of our journey together I'm gathering my thoughts to start my new thread for DCIS. Met with the surgeron today, I am stage 0, .6 cm, clear margins of "5MM or more", and my favorite few words "no evidence of invasion".
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Sunshine, I had never had surgery before and mine was also by general anesthesia. I was very nauseous afterwards - so I highly recommend making sure they prescribe nausea meds - just in case. Other than that, the anesthesia was just fine. I don't remember a thing! I was groggy that entire day, but feeling back to normal the following day. I agree with Pat though. Ask your anesthesiologist every question you can think of. You'll have an opportunity to meet with them the week or so prior to your surgery. Good luck and let us know when you are scheduled.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Oh Christina!!!! I'm so happy for you. It gives me goosebumps You have been through alot, but oh my gosh the peace of mind you must have. What great news. I hope you feel better soon and get back to life!
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: I'm over 50 and have been diagnosed with Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia after having a stereotactic needle biopsy. No lump, no mass, just a few tiny microcalcifications on my mammogram. I meet with a surgeron next week to schedule an open excision biopsy next to get rid of it completely. They tell you this isn't cancer, and I'm extremely thankful for that - but they sure seem to treat you like it is. I do have family history with BC. Has anyone out there also been diagnosed with this and what has your experience been like? Did you get a 2nd opinion? Did you opt to find out about your genetic marker? What is the impact of that on insurance and changing jobs? Did you decide to take tamoxifen or an even more radical approach? Just wondering if anyone has any wisdom/experience to share. Thanks for reading!
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Just thought I would post my excisional biopsy results. It turns out I have DCIS. I meet with the surgeon again on Monday and will know more then. I just wanted to complete my little story here to show that I ended up being in that percentage of women who do end up finding they have BC. I'm so thankful that I've caught it early.
Posts.Title: Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia 1 2 3 4

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota2004 and LadyAbby. Thank you so much for your posts today. The stereotactic procedure was a piece of cake i'm happy to report. Virtually painless. Now just the wait til next Tuesday to hear the final result. Thanks so much for being there. Thinking of you now Sarasota with your day next Wednesday. Will keep checking in.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota and LadyAbby, So glad to see your posts. I'm in the same boat and have the stereotactic scheduled next week. I have found other message boards that talk about how painful the procedure is and I'm scared. People seem to have a good experience or a terrible one. Has anyone had the procedure and can give feedback? Was thinking of asking my GP for something I could take prior. As I have thought about it, it seems since the microcalcifications are so so small and can't be felt that this is the only way. The radiologist mentioned that he thought they would remove them all during the procedure. Still it is terrifying news. I have 2 sisters that have had BC. Trying not to think about it. Sitting in those waiting rooms is tough. My hat is off to all of you who have gone before. You just don't quite realize until it's you sitting in that chair in the waiting room... The other thing i learned is that you shouldn't take ibuprofen or aspirin prior to your diagnostic mammogram. If you do, you have to wait 5 days before they will schedule your biopsy. I had never heard of this. Wish the radiology group had mentioned it. All this waiting, I would rather know - but then life could change forever.... Thanks for listening!
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Thank you LadyAbby. They have referred me to a surgeon that specializes in breast but does others as well. Its the radiologist saying to have an open excision biopsy. My appt with the surgeon is next Tuesday. I'm remaining positive, as I feel very fortunate that this is not cancer. Going through this will be worth it. Thinking of you Sarasota - good luck with your appointment tomorrow. Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Sarasota2004 - you are in my thoughts and prayers today. I'm sure you will be fine. The odds are overwhelmingly in your favor. One thing I wish I had mentioned earlier was that I asked my GP for a prescription for valium - just one pill to help me not be so nervous about the procedure. It really helped. If your appointment is this afternoon, get them to call in a prescrip for you.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Oh Sarasota!!! I'm so sorry you had to go through that. We really are on the same path somewhat eh? Yes, they did place a titanium marker in me at the end of the stereotactic procedure. From what I've been reading they'll have to give me a wire also at the time of the open biopsy to guide the surgeon. So maybe, look on the bright side, you are having one procedure and they will get to the bottom of it - the open biopsy is more definitive - instead of possibly having to have two procedures. Like you, I saw the xrays and I had three tiny grains of sand. I bet you will go through all of this just to learn everything is benign. Try to remain positive - remember the statistic is 80-85% are benign. Have they rescheduled you quickly so you don't have to wait?? My consultation is next Tuesday. I'll let you know what the Dr. says. I really feel for you. I'm sure you are emotionally exhausted!! Keep me posted.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Oh I hate you have to wait that long! Are you in a big city or a small town? That seems like a really long time to have to wait. Try to put it out of your mind til then (easier said than done). Keeping you in my thoughts. My surgeon's appt got pushed to next week - so I still don't know what I'm doing next either.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Thanks for your reply about your experience. That helps alot! I'll keep you posted. Thursday is my day.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Well I have my results and am thankful that I don't have cancer!!! BUT I have Atypical Ductal Hyperplasia, which is not cancer but makes me 5 times more at risk for cancer and the radiologist is suggesting a surgical biopsy next to make sure all has been removed. When I read online, some people actually see an oncologist for it. So getting a little scared again. Will keep you posted. Does anyone have experience with ADH??? Still thinking of you this week Sarasota, I hope your appt this week goes well. Let us know.
Posts.Title: Stereotactic biopsy - Confused 1 2

Posts.Content: Speaking of waiting... my surgery is set for 4/23. I guess I'll try to put it out of my mind til then.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi PF, It sounds like you have good news in that they are saying everything is benign. However, I know exactly how you feel in that you still aren't sure. Its like we get these other diagnoses, that we are thankful are benign,but make us feel like we aren't free and clear of worry anymore. I think you are smart to follow up with a breast specialist. Better to know all that you can and given that what they have found is so so early - I bet they'll just monitor you. I'm scheduled for an excisional biopsy on 4/23, I'll let you know how it goes. I hate the thought of being uneven too. Keep us posted.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota, Just wanted to say thinking of you this week. Don't you have an appt tomorrow??
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Oh Pat! My heart goes out to you! I'm so sorry your Mom passed away unexpectedly. Thinking of you and your family - I know you must miss her terribly. Just know you have friends out here praying for you. I'm thankful you had a good result. I know it pales in comparison to what you have going on. Keep in touch.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi Pfretzch, We're all in this together right now aren't we? It helps to know we are not alone going through this. The waiting is so hard! I completely understand. First of all, remember that even with all that you mention, the odds are still in your favor that results will come back benign! Try to focus on that. But I know its more like preparing for the worst and hoping for the best - especially when you are wide awake at 2am thinking about it! I also understand your questions. It would be nice to hear from women who have had lumpectomies and those who have even had mastectomies to tell us how they coped with the changes and feel about themselves afterwards. I have a sister that had a mastectomy and reconstruction and she is doing fine. Had no trouble dating and even got married again over 60. I had a stereotactic biopsy which came back with atypical ductal hyperplasia (ADH), and I'm now supposed to have an open excisional biopsy next. My appt with the surgeon to discuss it all is tomorrow. While ADH is not cancer, it greatly ups my risk of getting it in the future. That, and from reading the internet, I guess the excisional biopsy can come back with different results, so that scares me. Even if it is just ADH, it looks like they will suggest tamoxifen, and some women even opt for mastectomy. So, I guess I will find out more when I meet the surgeon, and after that set of results comes back. More waiting! Let us know when you get your results.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Pfretzsch - I'm right there with you. I was able to put this out of my mind for a few weeks but now that my excisional biopsy is looming on Friday... the nerves and the worry are right back.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota, How are you? I think you and I are facing the very same thing at the same time. I am still very scared. I find it comes and goes in waves. Today was hard. My test is scheduled for Thursday. Its getting closer and I have knots in my stomach and can't bring myself to tell anyone other than my husband. Did you get your appt scheduled? I don't think we can help but take it to the extreme. How can you not think about it all, prepare for the worst and hope for the best. I wish I could turn it off too.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota, I don't know about tamoxifen yet. What the surgeon said is that nationally, 41% of people with ADH stereotactic biopsy results - will find they have DCIS after the next step - excisional biopsy. Though his practice's average here in NC is 25%. 11% will find they have invasive breast cancer! So, I'm waiting for the excisional biopsy results. Then we talk next steps. So I"m a little down as I thought I was more 'out of the woods' than this. I try to dwell on the positive chances - that I have 75% of chance just ADH, and 90% chance not the other. Time will tell... Like you, trying to put it out of my mind for a month.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi All, I'm doing great! The anticipation of the procedure was the hardest part. I didn't feel a thing. As part of the procedure, they first insert a wire to tell the surgeon where to go - completely painless, then as soon as they start your IV - that's about all you remember.. you just wake up and its over. The only issue I had was that I was very nauseous and had a headache all day yesterday. I would suggest to anyone having the excision biopsy, to have their doctor write a prescription for pain meds AND nausea medicine... just in case you need it. We called in a precription late last night and after I took that I was fine. I basically slept all day and night, I was groggy all day yesterday too, but this morning I feel great. I don't really even feel the incision and I'm not taking any pain meds at all!!! Now just the wait for 5-7 days to hear the results. Thanks for checking on me. You guys are friends now Its so good we all have each other here.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi Pat, I had the stereotactic procedure done and it was completely painless and easy for me. The use Xray equipment from 2-3 angles and they went right to the spot and removed it! I saw on the before and after. My guess is it could be more exacting than the ultrasound. I'm sorry you are having to go through so much to reach a final determination. I know you must be frustrated. Let me know how it goes and if i can answer any more questions!
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi Pat, I've been thinking about you I hope your procedure went well this week. My internet has been down at home for almost three days! I wanted to wish you well beforehand. I'm so sorry that you are having to wait so long. The waiting is the hardest part. I'm doing well. Kind of in a lull where I can have a week or two of blissful denial before more treatment starts Have gathered alot of information, my genetics tests were good I don't have the BRCA 1/2 gene and I have also met with the radiologist/oncologist - to learn about that. Still trying to work out a 2nd opinion at Duke. But likely will start radiation in mid-June. I still have that little voice that is saying, should you just do a double mastectomy an be done with all this? Let us know how you are doing!!
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: I asked the same question... and the answer was no! If it is DCIS or worse, they go back in again and take a wider margin. I guess there is some chance that the next biopsy would have clear margins, but his answer was they go back in again. They know where to go because the stereotactic procedure left a marker. They'll insert a wire prior to the start of surgery so he knows where to go and will take a biopsy the size of a quarter or so - and remember I had three grains of sand (that's what the micro calcs looked like) that the stereotactic procedure took out.. I was confused, because on my mammogram you see nothing at all. He said you can't always see and feel breast cancer. Chances are I'm ok, but it was all a bit unsettling. I'm right with you on all that you said and questioned earlier.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Wow, that really sounds like good news for you. I hope you get to avoid surgery too! Mine is set for 4/23. I'll let you know how it goes.
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi Pat, Just thinking of you. Hope you are managing ok. . .
Posts.Title: How to cope while waiting 1 2 3

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota, I'm sorry you have this added concern on top of everything! If it were me, I would get a 2nd opinion from a major instutition. Your situation is unusual enough - size of your breast and location of microcalcs - that you may need the best of the best! Not saying anything derogatory about your doctors, but maybe someone who has had to do thousands of these, could help. Not sure what universities you are near, but I know the National Cancer Institute lists H. Lee Moffitt in Tampa for the state of Florida. At least have them review your films and doctors' comments and see what they suggest. I know you must be frustrated and still scared. Let us know what you decide to do next.
Posts.Title: What would you do? Surgical biopsy or 6 month follow-up???

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota, I feel for you! You just want some peace of mind regarding your decision. It would help if the physicians/radiologists were in agreement! I wonder if you could have your records sent to an institution like Duke, Mayo or Sloan Kettering - given your specific situation, and have a phone consultation regarding what they would recommend. I know I plan to get a 2nd opinion at Duke since I'm in NC. I've already talked to them, they just said to have everthing sent. I'll bet you can do it by phone if you are too far away.
Posts.Title: What would you do? Surgical biopsy or 6 month follow-up???

Posts.Content: Well, I've known since yesterday, but I've been sitting on it. I have not told anyone yet, not even my husband and hadn't even wanted to type it here.... it makes it real. It turns out I have DCIS. My surgeon's office called on Wednesday, he's at a conference, then he also called this morning and I meet with him on Monday. I'm just a bit stunned at the moment. Even though I knew it was a possibility....
Posts.Title: What would you do? Surgical biopsy or 6 month follow-up???

Posts.Content: Hi Sarasota, Thanks for the kind words. I think I'm finally coming out of shell-shocked mode You are right, I need to remain positive as this is the best possible diagnosis, if you have to receive one. I'll know alot more on Monday and keep you posted. Good luck making your decision. Let me know how Friday goes.
Posts.Title: What would you do? Surgical biopsy or 6 month follow-up???

Posts.Content: So glad to see these posts. I'm scheduled for the excisional on 4/23. Nervous. Glad to hear your down time was only one week. Could you be physically active after one week? I ride a horse and wonder how soon I can get back at it. The doctor says mine is really small but deep. He made it seem like they would take out a round shape the size of a quarter. Were you disfigured afterwards? Wide-excisional sounds so 'big'...
Posts.Title: Excisional/surgical biopsies - Any advice?
